message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain and symmetric swelling of hands and feet without any rashes suggests sickle cell crisis, which is caused by altered red blood cell morphology. The patient's history of obesity is also a risk factor for sickle cell disease. Trauma or infection would not cause symmetric swelling in both hands and feet. There is no evidence of a sexually transmitted infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain and swelling in the hands and feet, along with the history of obesity, suggests sickle cell disease or another form of altered red blood cell morphology. Trauma could cause edema, but it is unlikely to be symmetrical in the hands and feet. Sexually transmitted infections and viral infections do not typically present with this pattern of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain, swelling of hands and feet, and absence of rashes suggest altered red blood cell morphology, specifically sickle cell crisis. The physical exertion from playing football may have triggered the crisis. All other options are less likely given the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain and swelling in the hands and feet without a rash suggests vaso-occlusive crisis in sickle cell disease, which is characterized by altered red blood cell morphology. Trauma can be the cause but the presentation is not consistent with benign edema secondary to trauma. Sexually transmitted infection and viral infection are not likely causes of this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain and swelling of the hands and feet after playing football suggest sickle cell crisis, which is caused by altered red blood cell morphology. Benign edema secondary to trauma usually only affects the affected area, not both hands and feet. Sexually transmitted infections and viral infections do not typically present in this way.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of painful and symmetrical swelling of the hands and feet without any rash or signs of trauma suggests a vaso-occlusive crisis. Among the options, only altered red blood cell morphology can cause this type of crisis, which can be seen in sickle cell anemia, thalassemia, and other hemoglobinopathies. The history of obesity is not relevant to the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain, swelling, and symmetric involvement of the hands and feet suggest a vaso-occlusive crisis, which is commonly seen in sickle cell disease. Altered red blood cell morphology is a characteristic feature of sickle cell disease. Benign edema secondary to trauma, sexually transmitted infection, and viral infection are less likely causes of this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden pain, symmetrical swelling of hands and feet, and past medical history of obesity suggest sickle cell crisis, which is caused by altered red blood cell morphology. Trauma may cause edema but it would be localized to the site of injury, not symmetrical across the whole body. Sexually transmitted infections and viral infections are unlikely to present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain and swelling in the hands and feet, without any rash, suggest vaso-occlusive crisis. Thus, the most likely cause is altered red blood cell morphology, such as sickle cell disease, which is commonly associated with vaso-occlusive crisis. Trauma may lead to edema, but it typically involves a specific area rather than being symmetrical to both hands and feet. Sexually transmitted infections and viral infections are less likely to cause such symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain in the hands and feet, along with symmetrical swelling, points towards altered red blood cell morphology or sickle cell crisis. This is further supported by the patient’s history of obesity, which increases the risk of sickle cell disease. Trauma or physical exertion can trigger a sickle cell crisis. There is no indication of a sexually transmitted infection or viral infection. Analgesics are given to manage pain.
